metadata.title: Vulvodynia
description: The International Society for the Study of Vulvovaginal Disease (ISSVD) defines vulvodynia as vulvar pain lasting for at least 3 months. There are no clear, identifiable causes

Vulvodynia is not a synonym for vulvar pain. Vulvar pain may be associated with a specific condition, and there are several common etiologies. When the pain is idiopathic it is referred to as vulvodynia(2)
Vulvodynia is a diagnosis of exclusion. When no other cause for vulvar pain is identified, vulvodynia is diagnosed(13)

Classification of vulvodynia(13) –Localized (e.g., vestibulodynia, clitorodynia), generalized, or mixed (localized and generalized) –Provoked (e.g., Tampon insertion, physical contact), spontaneous, or mixed (provoked and spontaneous) –Onset (primary or secondary) –Temporal pattern (intermittent, persistent, constant, immediate, delayed)

May also be classified based on when the pain started(3) –Primary – vulvar pain started at the time of first coitus or first tampon insertion –Secondary – vulvar pain started after a period of pain-free intercourse –There is some evidence that the underlying mechanism of primary vulvodynia may be different from that of secondary vulvodynia, based on its different course(3) -In a study in the United States, women who had primary vulvodynia were 43% less likely than women with secondary vulvodynia to report remission(3)
Seven percent of women may experience some symptoms associated with vulvodynia by the age of 40(14)

ICD-10 codes.F52.6: Dyspareunia not due to a substance or known physiological condition
ICD-10 codes.N94.89: Other specified conditions associated with female genital organs
ICD-10 codes.N94.9: Unspecified condition associated with female genital organs (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Chronic pain (> 3 months) is the main symptom, described as(14) –burning (primary descriptor) –itching –stinging –rawness –irritation
Pain may be general (diffuse, without clear borders) or localized (e.g., vestibule)

Dyspareunia (painful intercourse) –Pain may be present from the onset of sexual activity (primary vulvodynia) or occur after years of pain-free intercourse (secondary vulvodynia) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Only clinicians trained in the evaluation/treatment of the pelvic floor and chronic vulvar pain should carry out portions of the evaluation of this region

Sexual history is an important component in evaluating patients with vulvodynia. Sensitivity is required when exploring sexual history –Therapists should obtain explicit patient permission prior to asking questions regarding sexual history –Obtaining sexual history should be deferred to a later part of the evaluation, allowing time to build a level of trust
Sexual history should be obtained with the patient clothed
Any observable lesions should be reported to the referring physician
Red flag findings –Hematuria –Unexplained weight loss or fatigue –Pain with urination –Abnormal menstruation –Breast abnormalities
A detailed pain assessment is part of the evaluation of a patient with vulvodynia. Sensitivity is required when questions regarding chronic pain are posed

causes: The exact etiology of vulvodynia is unknown. Most likely there is not one single etiology(4)–There are many unspecific theories in the literature, including the following:-Chronic inflammation of mucosal tissue-Studies have shown that women with had an increase in the amount of vestibular mucosa-associated  lymphoid tissuedue to local infection or inflammation provoked by vulvodynia than those without vulvodynia(9)-Vulvar mucosal hypersensitivity(4)-Genetic/immune factors(4)-Abnormalities of embryologic development(4)

Past theories of vulvodynia etiology that are no longer accepted by most vulvologists include chronic candidiasis,subclinical human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, childhood sexual abuse, and abnormalities of oxalate metabolism(2)
The prevalence of vulvodynia affects 8% of women in the United States
Psychological risk factors has also been associated with an increased risk of developing vulvodynia (see Risk Factors)
Contact with the vulvar area leads to increased tension in the levatorani muscle in response to a protective reaction(4)–Stress Response
pathogenesis: It is speculated that there may be an injury or irritation of the nerves that transmit pain from the vulva to the spinal cord,resulting in an increase in the number and sensitivity of nerve fibers(14)
risk factors: Women with genetic predispositions to infection, inflammation, and/or hormonal changes may be at higher risk forvulvodynia(15)

Psychological risk factors can increase the risk of developing vulvodynia and include(s):(15)–Depression or anxiety–Childhood maltreatment and/or victimization–Hypervigilance regarding pain–Fear avoidance–Lower pain self-efficacy  and pain acceptance
History of allergic reactions(4)–There is an association between mast cell–mediated  allergic reactions and onset of vulvodynia

overall contraindications precautions: Women with chronic vulvar pain should have a complete medical workup to determine whether a specific cause for the pain exists. Infection, specific inflammation, neoplasm, and neurogenic causes should be considered in the differential diagnosis
If an abusive situation is suspected, patient should be referred back to treating physician. Any jurisdiction-required  protocol should be observed
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Only clinicians trained in the evaluation/treatment of the pelvic floor and chronic vulvar pain should carry out portions of the evaluation of this region

Sexual history is an important component in evaluating patients with vulvodynia. Sensitivity is required when exploring sexual history –Therapists should obtain explicit patient permission prior to asking questions regarding sexual history –Obtaining sexual history should be deferred to a later part of the evaluation, allowing time to build a level of trust
Sexual history should be obtained with the patient clothed
Any observable lesions should be reported to the referring physician
Red flag findings –Hematuria –Unexplained weight loss or fatigue –Pain with urination –Abnormal menstruation –Breast abnormalities
A detailed pain assessment is part of the evaluation of a patient with vulvodynia. Sensitivity is required when questions regarding chronic pain are posed

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document history of the patient’s pain, including location, severity, timing, duration, causal/context factors, and associated symptoms. Document history of trauma and/or surgery, allergies, infections, and other pain conditions. Sexual history may be explored with patient permission

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about previous medical workup for infection (i.e., bacterial, viral, fungal, sexually transmitted), cancer, etc. A complete vaginal examination is typically performed In addition to physical therapy, treatment for vulvodynia often includes neuromodulation of spinal cord and peripheral nerve roots for intractable pain(4) psychotherapy, with a focus on pain management and sexuality(4) Surgery may be performed on patients with provoked vestibular vulvodynia specifically(14)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective?(13) Amitriptyline Gabapentin Lidocaine Baclofen(12) antinociceptive agents (lidocaine, capsaicin) anti-inflammatory  agents (corticosteroids, interferon) neuromodulating medications (anticonvulsants, antidepressants) hormonal agents and muscle relaxants (botulinum toxin)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Cotton swab test  used to localize and quantify pain involving the vulva
Electrodiagnostic testing  motor and nerve function(4)
Electromyography of the levatorani and nerve conduction testing of the pudendal nerve may be performed if a pudendal nerve injury or entrapment is suspected
Vulvar biopsy is recommended to exclude other etiologies such as inflammatory or neoplastic dermatoses(4)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, nutritional or herbal supplements) and whether they help Results of a randomized wait-list  controlled pilot study of acupuncture for the treatment of vulvodynia conducted in the United States indicate that acupuncture appears to reduce vulvar pain and dyspareunia and increase overall sexual function(5) Larger double-blind  RCTs are needed
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Ask if symptoms are aggravated by voiding or intercourse -Factors associated with pain in women with vulvodynia include intercourse, tight clothing, partner touch, riding a bicycle, use of tampons, and prolonged sitting -Factors associated with pain relief include wearing loose clothing, not wearing underwear, distraction, application of ice, and lying down
history of present illness.body chart: Use a body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -The discomfort of vulvodynia is most often characterized as perceptions of burning, rawness, or irritation(2) -Sensations of stabbing, tearing, aching, soreness, and stinging are sometimes described(2) -Chronic unexplained itching occasionally is a manifestation of vulvodynia, but when itch is present it is not an itch that produces a desire to rub or scratch(2) -Pain during intercourse (dyspareunia) is nearly always present(2) -Pain during intercourse may be assessed by frequency of occurrence and duration of symptoms; does pain occur during, after, or both? -The Neuropathic Pain Diagnostic Questionnaire (DN4) may be used to detect neuropathic pain(6)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. Is pain related to the menstrual cycle?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., symptoms of depression or PTSD, bowel/bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document any reported respiratory issues or compromise Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Have other conditions involving the urogenital system been diagnosed in the patient? If patient has been pregnant, document course(s) of pregnancy and any complications Has the patient undergone any surgeries in the abdominal or lumbopelvic regions? Does the patient have a previous history of hip, lumbosacral, or pelvic pain or trauma?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including chronic pain, chronic infections, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Common comorbid conditions include chronic fatigue syndrome, fibromyalgia, endometriosis, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis, depression, and anxiety(4) Vulvodynia was more prevalent in women who screened positive for depression or PTSD compared to women who screened negative for these conditions(7) Based on data from 1,795 women participating in a multiethnic population-based  study in the United States  According to the U.S. National Vulvodynia Registry, the most common pain comorbidities reported by women with vulvodynia were migraines (34%), chronic pelvic pain (22%), and irritable bowel syndrome (20%). Also, 41% of patients complained of anxiety, 90% had localized vestibular pain, and 90% had muscular abnormalities in the vaginal region detected in examination(10) Based on gynecologic evaluation and sensory assessment of pressure, pain sensitivity, as well as psychometric questionnaires to assess pain, distress, sexual function, and quality of life, in 176 women experiencing vulvodynia
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Does the patient work? Does the patient have current restrictions in recreational or vocational activities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Symptoms of vulvodynia may be severe enough to interfere with ADLs. Document any reported impairments and/or coping strategies
social and occupational history.living environment: stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Note structural components of the lumbopelvis and/or lower extremities that might contribute to pelvic floor dysfunction (e.g., leg length)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Complete a gait assessment and document pelvic mobility during gait. Observe spinal and hip movements during gait activitiesAssess lumbopelvic mobility and stability. Spinal, sacral, and pelvic alignment should be checkedAssess for atypical muscle tone
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manual muscle testing (MMT) of trunk and extremities (especially hips) should be performedassess the muscles of the pelvic floor starting with the puborectalis and working towards the pelvic musculature(14)
observation inspection palpation includi: Cotton swab exam: assess the vestibule from the outside in and mark the area/ location of pain(14) •Palpation:  Palpation of the abdominal, hip, and spinal muscles should be completed
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Perform a thorough assessment of spinal, pelvic, and hip movement and muscle flexibility
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess reflexes for grade and symmetryDocument impairments related to vulvodynia or comorbid conditions –Inquire about bowel and bladder function
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess for sensory impairment or hypersensitivity assess patient’s ability to differentiate cotton swab versus pinprick and determine if sensation is normal, hyposensitive, sharp, burning, or shooting(14)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –Female Sexual Function Index (FSFI)T708587 –Cotton swab test may be performed by a trained clinician
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Some psychotropic medications have side effects that impact this domain

contraindications precautions: Do not use laser with pregnant women, patients with epilepsy, or patients with infections
Do not use over the unclosed fontanelles of children
Do not use over cancerous lesions, the mediastinum, areas of impaired sensation, sympathetic ganglia, the vagus nerve, the gonads, the cornea, endocrine glands, or hemorrhaging lesions
Goggles with an appropriate optical density rating should be worn by the patient
Presence of or tendency for hemorrhage or edema
electrotherapy contraindications precaut: Do not place electrodes near carotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators, phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads
Osteomyelitis
Hemorrhage
Impaired sensation, mental status, communication
Cardiovascular disease
Malignancy
Dermatological conditions
Proximity of electromagnetic radiation
In pregnant women, near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, or abdomen
In patients with stroke or seizures, near the neck
History of spontaneous abortion in pregnant women
over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
over the eyes or testes
in an area with infection or bleeding
if a tumor or malignancy is present in the area
in the area of a DVT or thrombophlebitis
over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
over epiphyseal plates
Sensory deficits
Ineffective communication skills in a patient (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Circulatory impairments
Plastic or metal implants
Peripheral vascular disease ›Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications; do not use
contraindications precautions.general: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Vulvodynia has a negative impact on the patient’s quality of life and sexual functioning. Pain, disability, and impairments associated with vulvodynia may be decreased by physical therapy treatment
assessment plan of care.rule out: Vulvodynia is a diagnosis of exclusion. Other causes of vulvar pain resulting from urogenital infection, inflammation, other neurological causes/chronic pain syndromes, and cancer must be ruled out. Specific entities include pudendal canal syndrome, vaginismus, and chronic pelvic pain
prognosis: Women with severe symptoms are less likely to improve their symptoms(2)
Severe comorbidities, marked anxiety or depression, catastrophization, and intolerance to medications are indicators of poor prognosis(2)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: The clinician should maintain close communication with the referring physician (usually gynecologist). Referral to other physician specialists may be indicated Psychosocial issues (e.g., sexual impairment, abuse, depression, anxiety) may require referral to psychiatrist or psychologist Refer cases of suspected abuse to the physician and/or the appropriate authority Results of a study conducted in Canada strongly suggest that a multidisciplinary hospital-based  program that integrates psychological, pelvic floor physiotherapy, and gynecological management in a single setting is effective(8) –It was noted that women often seek these therapies in succession. Treatment with a multidisciplinary team of professionals concurrently may be more acceptable to women, as was indicated by their rate of program completion
other considerations: Somatocognitive therapy (SCT) may significantly improve the recovery process for those experiencing provoked vestibulodynia(11) –SCT is similar to meditation in that the goal is to release any physical tension that is occurring in the body after a traumatic event –SCT follows three principal concepts: -Promoting awareness of the body -“Focusing” energy in the painful pubic region of the body
treatment summary: Pelvic floor physical therapy may reduce the symptoms of vulvodynia in most women(14) –A physical therapy treatment program for vulvodynia includes exercise, massage, soft tissue, and joint mobilization –Use of dilators after physical therapy treatment is recommended(14)
The primary purpose of participating in a physical therapy program is to retrain and maintain the muscles of the pelvic floor in order to improve strength and voluntary muscle relaxation(13)

Modalities such as electromyographic feedback and electrical stimulation have been shown to minimize pain during sexual intercourse and enhance sexual function and overall quality of life(15) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Altered pelvic floor muscle function, increased tone, decreased contractilityDecrease tone, increase contractility and controlManual therapy _ Soft tissue mobilization (internal and external) _ _ Trigger point release _ _ Therapeutic exercise Contraction and relaxation exercises for 9 pelvic floor muscles _ _ Modalities _ Nerve block, neuroelectrical stimulation _Progress each individual patient as indicated and toleratedExercises to improve neuromuscular control and function should be incorporated into home program. Instruction on frequency and duration of exercises should be provided and reinforced during treatment Decreased soft tissue mobility and flexibilityIncrease soft tissue mobility and flexibility of target areas, including trunk, inner thighs, perineal region, abdominal and hip musclesManual therapy  Soft tissue mobilization, myofascial release, neural mobilization (pudendal nerve), visceral mobilization (urogenital/GI tract) _ Therapeutic exercise Flexibility exercise, as indicated _Progress each individual patient as indicated and toleratedFlexibility and ROM exercises should be incorporated into the home program Pain and sensitivity to pressure and touchDecrease pain _ Decrease sensitivityModalities   (13,14) _ TENS, vaginal dilator, biofeedback _ _

increased frequency of intercourse and p: Self-report  of symptoms related to intercourse and ADLs

maintenance or prevention: The patient is advised to continue her prescribed home program and follow up with the appropriate healthcare professionals as indicated

The National Vulvodynia Registry was established in the United States to(10) develop multidimensional assessment tools that reflect routine clinical practice collect data on patient characteristics before and after treatment identify immune and genetic biomarkers that will help classify women with vulvodynia into therapeutically relevant subtypes (e.g., pain characteristics, clinical exam, psychological functioning, sexual function)
